Award.AwardTitle: Some Questions in Low-Dimensional and Contact Topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to carry out research on several interrelated topics in contact and low-dimensional topology. A "contact structure'' is an extra geometric structure on a manifold (these structures originate from physics); the study of contact structures and knots in contact manifolds draws on ideas from different fields (geometry, algebra, combinatorics). This project will contribute to the development of these areas, especially to geometry of manifolds. The main part of the project concerns the investigation of "right-handed'' and "left-handed'' properties of certain knots. Related ideas often appear in the broader context of geometry, algebra, and physics.

This project will focus on two different topics. The first topic concerns knot theory and contact topology in dimension 3, and is related to knot invariants of gauge-theoretic and combinatorial nature. The project's goal is to develop properties and applications for a special class of transverse knots (those with certain "positivity" properties); the PI expects to find relations between algebraic properties of corresponding braids, behavior of invariants from knot Floer and Khovanov homology (including an invariant introduced by the PI in 2006), properties of symplectic surfaces (cobordisms) connecting the knots, and rigidity of their branched double covers. This investigation develops a novel approach (with a focus on braid group orderings and the braid monodromy) but also continues the PI's past research. The PI also plans to continue studying flexible phenomena in higher-dimensional contact topology and expects to contribute to this rapidly developing area. The goal is to better understand properties of rigid/flexible contact manifolds, developing analogs of existing results in dimension 3.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Stony Brook
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI works in geometry, studying 3- and 4-dimensional spaces equipped with additional objects such as contact structures (two-dimensional plane fields) and symplectic structures, as well as knots in 3-dimensional manifolds.

One of the major goals of the project was to study the geometric meaning of certain invariants of knots/braids transverse to contact structures in 3-manifolds. The PI found interesting relations between objects an invariants arising in very different contexts, relating contact-geometric properties of knots and their Floer invariants (defined analytically and combinatorially) to dynamics of the monodromy (twisting of the braid) and algebra (Dehornoy's ordering on braid group).

Another direction of research was concerned with topology of singularities of complex surfaces and its interplay with contact and symplectic topology. The specific focus was  the study of contact structures that arise on links of isolated complex surface singularities. On a complex surface (defined by some algebraic equations in the space), an isolated singular point is a cusp-like sharp point in an otherwise smooth region. The link is equipped with a canonical contact structure (a 2-plane field) given by complex tangencies. The PI's work sheds new light on the interplay between contact, symplectic topology and low-dimensional topology and singularity theory. With J.Bodnar, she found  special properties of canonical contact structures on a link of singularity, using combinatorial methods (lattice homology) in a novel way.  With P.Ghiggini and M.Golla, she established that planar contact sructures (a topological property) are in exact correspondence with minimal singularities (an algebraic property). With L.Starkston (work in progress) she developed a framework for symplectic fillings of minimal singularities that parallels the deformation theory of De Jong-Van Straten but uses symplectic rather than algebro-geometric tools.

The PI's work had significant broader impacts, as she actively worked with graduate students and postdocs and organized research and learning seminars. She served as a project co-leader at a workshop for women in symplectic geometry, helping to create a network for longer-term collaborations and  advance participation of women in mathematics. The PI serves as the Associate Undergraduate Director at her institution, contributing to undergraduate education.

During the grant period, the PI wrote and published several research papers and presented her research at a number of conferences and seminars; she makes her work available in the online research preprint archive.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2019
Modified by: Olga Plamenevskaya
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The PI works in geometry, studying 3- and 4-dimensional spaces equipped with additional objects such as contact structures (two-dimensional plane fields) and symplectic structures, as well as knots in 3-dimensional manifolds. One of the major goals of the project was to study the geometric meaning of certain invariants of knots/braids transverse to contact structures in 3-manifolds. The PI found interesting relations between objects an invariants arising in very different contexts, relating contact-geometric properties of knots and their Floer invariants (defined analytically and combinatorially) to dynamics of the monodromy (twisting of the braid) and algebra (Dehornoy's ordering on braid group). Another direction of research was concerned with topology of singularities of complex surfaces and its interplay with contact and symplectic topology. The specific focus was the study of contact structures that arise on links of isolated complex surface singularities. On a complex surface (defined by some algebraic equations in the space), an isolated singular point is a cusp-like sharp point in an otherwise smooth region. The link is equipped with a canonical contact structure (a 2-plane field) given by complex tangencies. The PI's work sheds new light on the interplay between contact, symplectic topology and low-dimensional topology and singularity theory. With J.Bodnar, she found special properties of canonical contact structures on a link of singularity, using combinatorial methods (lattice homology) in a novel way. With P.Ghiggini and M.Golla, she established that planar contact sructures (a topological property) are in exact correspondence with minimal singularities (an algebraic property). With L.Starkston (work in progress) she developed a framework for symplectic fillings of minimal singularities that parallels the deformation theory of De Jong-Van Straten but uses symplectic rather than algebro-geometric tools. The PI's work had significant broader impacts, as she actively worked with graduate students and postdocs and organized research and learning seminars. She served as a project co-leader at a workshop for women in symplectic geometry, helping to create a network for longer-term collaborations and advance participation of women in mathematics. The PI serves as the Associate Undergraduate Director at her institution, contributing to undergraduate education. During the grant period, the PI wrote and published several research papers and presented her research at a number of conferences and seminars; she makes her work available in the online research preprint archive.
